subject: Re: [junit] Invariants: method within class or within test class?
msgSnippet: I find that option #1 is superior. As you say, it reduces exposure to internals. It also gives one the option of invoking that code in the field. Especially
messageBody:
I find that option #1 is superior. As you say, it reduces exposure to
internals. It also gives one the option of invoking that code in the
field. Especially where there are user accessable APIs, I find it handy to
ask a user to invoke invariants checking around problem code while
diagnosing a possible API bug. If your assertInvariants(..) method is
recursive, it is also not difficult to add a menu option that will invoke
a full internal state check at run-time.

I always have the invariants checks run in my unit tests. This gives you
the ability to catch a lot more bugs and get better diagnostics resorting
to soak testing. A lot of times, your unit test may pass but leave the
class-under-test in a bad state. In a real program, the next statement
would fail, but its never caught in your test because the fixture is
recycled. Invoking the invariants tests after state changes in tests is
cheap and saves headaches in the long run.

On Fri, 14 Dec 2001, Robertson, Don wrote:

> Let's assume that invoking an assertInvariants() method within your class's
> methods is too expensive to be practical, but you want it for the purpose of
> unit testing anyway. Would it be structurally superior to :
>
> 1) Implement such a method within the actual class and invoke it from the
> test case. The main benefits I see are minimal exposure of the class's
> internals (although it *is* white box testing after all), and visual
> proximity of the invariant conditions for implementors/modifiers. The
> negative is that there is "dead code" (from a runtime perspective) within
> the class.
> 2) Allow access to internal state within the class and write the
> assertInvariants() method within the test class(es). The benefits are visual
> proximity of the invariant conditions with the other functional description
> of the class, and no dead code in the runtime class. The negative is the
> need for exposure of more internal state.
>
> Opinions?
>
>
> A second "meta" question might be whether you think it is worthwhile to
> check invariant conditions within your unit tests as a default behavior, or
> is it overkill?
>
> Don
>
>
